1989, a new administration comes in.

This should all sound familiar.
And in 1989, President Bush, the first one, signs new legislation, banking reform.
He walks out into the Rose Garden to make a speech and Lawrence Kaplan is watching it happen on TV.
He remembers the moment well.
We, a group of lawyers, went to the rooftop of the Hotel Washington.

Got rid of you guys.
He got rid of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
What happened is, we walked back and it was amazing because they changed the name on the building already.
It said the Office of Thrift Supervision.

They didn't get rid of the agency on the org chart, they just renamed it.
And the regulators went back to work.
Sure, there were new rules, new leadership, but the people stayed the same.
Except Kaplan, he moved on to work in the private sector.
And to be clear, Kaplan says he and his colleagues did not mess up.
Regulators could only enforce the rules as they were written.
And in the early 1980s, Congress changed the rules on them.
Thrifts were allowed to take too many risks, so Kaplan says the regulators' hands were tied.
But here is what happened next.
The renamed agency, the OTS, later became regulator of Washington Mutual, AIG and Countrywide, all key players in our current financial crisis.
And so, Congress is now sitting down to rewrite banking reform.
Here's Lawrence Kaplan again.
What's happening now, both the House and the Senate bills propose eliminating the OTS, merging its functions into other agencies so that...
Just like what happened to you.
Basically, 20 years later, history is repeating itself.
Unfortunately, you know, the biggest problem in regulation is they're enforced by people.
This is Vincent Reinhart.
He's an economist with the American Enterprise Institute.
And we talked for a long time about a catchy economic phrase for what is happening here - regulatory capture.

The idea is basically that the industry being regulated - in this case it's banks, but it could be oil, mining, whatever - that industry will always work overtime to capture two groups of people, the people writing the rules, Congress and the people enforcing the rules, regulators like the people at the OTS.
And the industry will use lots of capture tactics.
They'll use money, time, gifts, they'll help write legislation, they'll help regulators fill out complicated forms.
Reinhart says the industry does this all the time and not just during a crisis.
Over time, the government sees its rules aren't being enforced effectively.
So it makes its rules more complicated.
But if it's more complicated, then the private sector just spends even more resources to figure out ways to get around the rules.
And the government makes the rules even more complicated.
And at no point have we even gotten to moral failure and greed.
You know who's really susceptible to moral failure and greed?
People.
Reinhart says considering it is people who write the rules and people who enforce the rules, that impulse to make regulation more complicated is all wrong.
They're afraid of retaliation.

One of the major recommendations was for those that are severely injured, they need both a recovery plan and a recovery coordinator.

The reason for that is, that their injuries are so complex, that the idea of their families giving up their jobs and giving up their homes and coming out to a major medical center and having to spend the time coordinating their care is simply unacceptable.
And so hiring a professional to do that who's not going to be deployed next month back to Iraq or Afghanistan is very important to the quality of their care and to their own future.
And so the recovery coordinators are being hired, and we've always had care coordinators in the system.
But when you have something that's really complex, you need a single person that does all the pieces for you, right until you get the benefits that you're eligible for.
We spoke with Dr. C.

Martin Harris of the Cleveland Clinic, who served on your commission, and he also said that of the things on the table was possibly to extend the Family Medical and Leave Act for caretakers of wounded veterans.
Did that go anywhere?
Is that in process?
As a matter of fact, that was introduced by a bipartisan group of members of Congress.
And it certainly passed one house, and I'm not quite sure where it is right now.
But I do believe that will be, that will be implemented right away.
That's not a very complex one.

But what was needed more than anything else, is the - making the system very seamless and not depending on family members to do all of the work that a professional health care person ought to be doing.
And we ought to be paying for that kind of service, particularly for these very complex cases.
This Commission came into fruition after reports that returning soldiers weren't getting adequate medical care at Walter Reed.
Is there a sense now that the country is moving in a better direction in terms of making veterans a priority?
Yes.
But, remember, it wasn't that they weren't getting first-class medical care.
It was at the facilities after they left the hospital that single individuals were placed in, were terrible facilities - the famous building 18 I guess it was, at Walter Reed.
Has that been cleaned up?
I think the Administration moved immediately on Walter Reed.
The underlying problem, though, is the fragmentation of the health care system and our need to make it seamless.
And that includes having a seamless medical record, so that when you leave the care of the military and go to the VA, it's a seamless transition for you.
Working with Bob Dole, who is himself a recovered war vet who had serious injuries that he will carry with him for the rest of his life, what did you learn about what it must be like?
Most of us will never be in that position, but what did you learn from working with him or from just doing this work in general?

Well, in addition to Senator Dole, who, of course, received his injuries which are life-changing in World War II, we had two recent veterans for the Iraqi war, both of whom were severely injured, on our panel, and the wife of an injured service member and another disabled health care leader who heads the Washington Rehab Center.
So we had a lot of people with real day-to-day expertise.
And I'll tell you what we learned.
We learned to listen to people who have actually been through the experience in terms of what they needed to recover and what they needed to have successful lives.

It was, for me, a remarkable experience because the panel was not made up of the usual suspects who represented major constituencies, but rather of people who had real life experience who could talk about those experiences.
And as a result, our recommendations were patient-centered.
What about mental illness.
There's been a spike in suicide among veterans.
There's been a lot of brain injuries that could affect mood as well as other things.
How much did you focus on the mental dimensions ofâ€¦
We did.
How much, and what did you recommend specifically on that count?
One of our major recommendations - remember, we only had six recommendations.
We recommended lifetime care for those who have post traumatic stress disorder as well, of course, as those that were already covered with TBI, traumatic brain injury.

In addition to that, it became very apparent as we listened to both the wounded warriors, their families, as well as the military themselves that this mental health has taken on a different dimension.
This is a war of head injuries, and it's a war in which for the first time, we are embedding mental health professionals into the units themselves.
And we're just at the beginning of learning about all of these things.
But I think that the military is as up to date as anyone that I know about trying to get out to the field and anticipate and treat as quickly as possible these traumatic experiences.
Now the president's fiscal year 2009 budget provides $41 billion for veterans' medical care.
That's an increase of $2.3 billion from the 2008 budget.
Is that enough of an increase to get done some of the many things we've talked about?
Well, let me put it this way.
Much of what we recommended required that both the military and the VA do things differently - not necessarily new resources, but some of the things we recommended definitely require new resources.
The president has started the process of investing in those resources that are needed.
But I'm never going to say we've done enough or we have enough resources dedicated to these brave young men and women.
Now since you served as a cabinet official during the Clinton administration, you must know intimately what it takes to keep your issues on the agenda.

And in an environment like there is today, with an election going on, with the war going on, with the economy, what does it take for someone, you know, whether it's someone who is inside the Bush administration or people who are in Congress, what does it take to keep veterans health on the agenda in a time when there's so many competing demands?
They responded in self-defense.
Enemy continued firing.
They saw what they believed to be some kind of anti-aircraft up and coming out of the building.
Well, it obviously takes political leadership.
It also takes administrative leadership.
And what's impressive is that Secretary Gates and the new secretary of VA, have their deputies meeting on a regular basis to discuss the recommendations and how far they are in the implementation.

My own experience is that the bureaucracy, if it's committed, can get more done when the White House and the rest of the political leadership is distracted because there's no interference and they're not asking you to do all sorts of other things.
So that I believe that these meet - a combination of these meetings and the White House domestic policy staff literally keeping an eye on every detail really does make a difference.
And I believe there has been progress.
It's why we wrote a very strategic report, putting most of the pressure on the president.

Now our major recommendations on disability, on changing the disability system, on modernizing it, are not yet getting bipartisan, serious attention from the Congress, and that's in large part because of the politics that are going on at this time.
It's been five years since the start of this war.
Five years from now, where would you like to see veterans health care?
Well, look, I don't think we should take five years.
I think a year after the election, we should get every single piece in place, including the recommendations on disability.
And getting, modernizing the disability system is critical.
And there's some disagreement among the veterans groups.
Some believe that this generation of veterans should not get different benefits than previous generations.
I think each generation ought to get better benefits.
That's the way I feel about myself.
I hope that the new generation gets a better education, has a better opportunity for our future.
And that's the way we ought to think about Americans.
We ought to want each generation to have better opportunities and better resources so that they can live better lives.
